metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: Polygon comes from Greek. "Poly" means "many" and "gon" means "angle".
content.html: Polygon comes from Greek. "Poly" means "many" and "gon" means "angle".

content.text: The <polygon> element is used to create a graphic that contains at least three sides.
content.html: The <polygon> element is used to create a graphic that contains at least three sides.

content.text: Polygons are made of straight lines, and the shape is "closed" (it automatically connects the last point with the first).
content.html: Polygons are made of straight lines, and the shape is "closed" (it automatically connects the last point with the first).

content.text: The <polygon> element has one basic attribute that defines the points of the polygon:
content.html: The <polygon> element has one basic attribute that defines the points of the polygon:

content.code_html:
Attribute Description
points Required. The list of points of the polygon. Each point must contain an x coordinate and a y coordinate

content.text: The following example creates a polygon with three sides:
content.html: The following example creates a polygon with three sides:

content.code_html:
<svg height="220" width="500" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <polygon points="100,10 150,190 50,190" style="fill:lime;stroke:purple;stroke-width:3" />
</svg>

content.text: The following example creates a polygon with four sides:
content.html: The following example creates a polygon with four sides:

content.code_html:
<svg height="260" width="500" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <polygon points="220,10 300,210 170,250 123,234" style="fill:lime;stroke:purple;stroke-width:3" />
</svg>

content.text: The following example creates a polygon with six sides:
content.html: The following example creates a polygon with six sides:

content.code_html:
<svg height="280" width="360" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <polygon points="150,15 258,77 258,202 150,265 42,202 42,77"
  style="fill:lime;stroke:purple;stroke-width:3" />
</svg>

content.text: Use the <polygon> element to create a star:
content.html: Use the <polygon> element to create a star:

content.code_html:
<svg height="210" width="500" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <polygon points="100,10 40,198 190,78 10,78 160,198"
  style="fill:lime;stroke:purple;stroke-width:5;" />
</svg>

content.text: Use the fill-rule attribute to specify the inside part of a shape:
content.html: Use the fill-rule attribute to specify the inside part of a shape:

content.code_html:
<svg height="210" width="500" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <polygon points="100,10 40,198 190,78 10,78 160,198"
  style="fill:lime;stroke:purple;stroke-width:5;fill-rule:evenodd;" />
</svg>
